title-group.article-title: The educational rights of persons with disabilities
title-group.subtitle: International human rights law and Australian law perspectives

author-notes.corresp: Douglas Hodgson, University of Notre Dame Australia, School of Law, Fremantle, Western Australia, Australia. Email: doug.hodgson@nd.edu.au

abstract.p: Since the founding of the United Nations in 1945, the human rights normative framework pertaining to persons with disabilities has expanded exponentially. In terms of international public policy, it is now recognised that discrimination against persons with disabilities is a violation of the inherent dignity and worth of the human person. This paper proposes to examine those human rights which such persons now enjoy specifically in relation to the human right to education. The first part of the paper will provide a historical overview of the systematic development of the recognition of the educational rights of persons with disabilities under the auspices of the United Nations, with particular emphasis upon the Convention on the Rights of the Child 1989 and the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities 2006. Brief mention will also be made of the recognition of such rights under regional human rights systems. Other non-binding UN instruments such as the World Programme of Action concerning Disabled Persons 1982 and the Standard Rules on the Equalization of Opportunities for Persons with Disabilities 1993 will also be analysed. The second part of the article will then consider how these international standards have been adopted and applied in Australian law and policy. It will specifically consider the relevant provisions of the Commonwealth of Australia’s Disability Discrimination Act 1992 and the Disability Standards for Education 2005 which have been enacted thereunder as well as case-law of Australian courts.

The aims of this article are threefold: (i) to identify and discuss impediments to the fuller realisation of the educational rights of persons with disabilities; (ii) to compare and contrast the extent and impact of the international and national legal recognition and protection afforded to persons with disabilities in the educational context; and (iii) to identify strategies for securing more effective implementation of the right to education of persons with disabilities. While the UN has excelled in formulating relevant and noble treaty obligations and aspirational principles in this area, the author argues that the next developmental stage must systematically address practical measures which can deliver meaningful and objectively verifiable progress in the monitoring and implementation of these rights. While international human rights law has long influenced legislative initiatives and policy development in UN Member States, it is the author’s contention that, in this particular field, UN treaty-monitoring bodies can equally and reciprocally be informed by relevant State practice including that offered by the Australian experience.

[T]he physical and mental handicaps which affect millions of children all over the world ought also to be given particular attention, for it is essential, both for moral and for economic reasons, that such children, to whom fate has been unkind but who are perfectly capable of overcoming their handicaps, should not be excluded from the life of society; they have a right to an education adapted to their situation.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: It is estimated that there are 500–650 million persons with disabilities (approximately 10% of the world’s population), 150 million of whom are children. Sadly, many of the causes of disability, such as armed conflict, illness, disease and poverty, are preventable. More than 80% live in developing countries with access to very limited services. The majority of children with disabilities residing in developing countries remain out of school and are functionally illiterate. Often the extent of the disability is aggravated and the period during which it is suffered is prolonged because of a lack of early/timely intervention. 1 The United Nations Committee on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights has observed that ‘The effects of disability-based discrimination have been particularly severe in the fields of [inter alia] education’. 2

The term ‘disability’ encompasses a significant number of different functional limitations. People may suffer disability through physical, intellectual, mental or sensory impairment or through medical conditions, either transitory or permanent in nature, resulting in hearing, sight or speech problems. Various international human rights instruments have attempted to define the term ‘disability’. For example, Paragraph 1 of the Declaration on the Rights of Disabled Persons proclaimed by the United Nations General Assembly in Resolution 3447 (XXX) of 9 December 1975 defines the term ‘disabled person’ as ‘any person unable to ensure by himself of herself, wholly or partly, the necessities of a normal individual and/or social life, as a result of deficiency, either congenital or not, in his or her physical or mental capabilities.’ 3 For the purposes of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities 2006 , ‘persons with disabilities’ is defined in Article 1 thereof ‘to include those who have long-term physical, mental, intellectual or sensory impairments which in interaction with various barriers may hinder their full and effective participation in society on an equal basis with others.’ 4 Indeed, preambular paragraph (e) of the Disabilities Convention recognises disability as a dynamic and ‘evolving concept’ and that ‘disability results from the interaction between persons with impairments and attitudinal and environmental barriers that hinder their full and effective participation in society on an equal basis with others.’

The concept of education can be variously defined. Education occurs in its widest sense in the interaction of the individual with the social and natural environment to which he or she belongs. Education can be defined in the broad sense to encompass ‘all activities by which a human group transmits to its descendants a body of knowledge and skills and a moral code which enable that group to subsist’ (M’Bow, 1979: 11). In this sense, then, education is primarily concerned with the transmission to the younger generation of the skills necessary to effectively undertake the tasks of daily living and with the inculcation of the social, cultural, religious and philosophical values held by the particular community.

Education can, in turn, be more narrowly defined to refer to formal or professional ‘instruction imparted within a national, provincial or local education system, whether public or private’ (M’Bow, 1979: 11). It is generally the case that the term ‘education’ is used in international instruments to refer to formal institutional instruction. For example, the General Conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) has defined the term ‘education’ for the purposes of its Convention against Discrimination in Education 1960 to mean ‘all types and levels of [formal] education, and includes access to education, the standard and quality of education, and the conditions under which it is given’. 5 The European Court of Human Rights has distinguished education in its wide sense from education in its narrow sense in the following terms:

disp-quote.p: [education in the wider sense refers to] the whole process whereby, in any society, adults endeavour to transmit their beliefs, culture and other values to the young, whereas teaching or instruction refers in particular to the transmission of knowledge and to intellectual development. 6

sec.p:
For the purposes of this paper, ‘education’ will refer to state-sponsored and taxpayer-funded formal teaching or institutional instruction, as well as private sector education, comprising the pre-primary, primary (elementary), secondary and tertiary levels of education as well as adult education. Education in both its wider and narrower meanings is particularly important for laying the foundations for the meaningful participation of persons with disabilities in society throughout their lives. Indeed, Article 13(1) of the United Nations International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights 1966
7 explicitly acknowledges that one of the key outcomes of education is to ‘enable all persons to participate effectively in a free society’ (emphasis added).

This article will begin by tracing the recent historical development of the human right to education as it has been applied to persons with disabilities under international human rights law, particularly under United Nations auspices since 1945. The normative framework contained in both legally binding international treaties and non-binding aspirational or programmatic principles found in various international declarations will be examined and compared with, and contrasted with, the manner in which the Commonwealth of Australia has attempted to proscribe disability-based discrimination in education through the enactment of the Disability Discrimination Act 1992 and the Disability Standards for Education 2005 . Specific concepts such as ‘reasonable adjustment’ and ‘unjustifiable hardship’ will be analysed in this context. Various obstacles to the fuller realisation of the educational rights of persons with disabilities will be identified and relevant issues discussed. This will include whether the apparent trend towards greater integration and inclusion of persons with disabilities in the educational process can ever be displaced and, if so, in what limited circumstances, without infringing such rights. The concluding section will consider how the educational rights of persons with disabilities may be better implemented, as well as the potential for the Australian law and policy in this area to inform and shape the pronouncements of UN treaty monitoring bodies which deal directly with these issues.

sec.title: The formative international human rights law normative framework concerning the educational rights of persons with disabilities
The declaratory framework
sec.p:
Only one reference to ‘disability’ appears in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights 1948
8 in a general rather than an educational context. Article 25(1) provides in part that ‘[e]veryone has the right to security in the event of unemployment, sickness, disability, widowhood, old age or other lack of livelihood in circumstances beyond his control’. Nevertheless, Article 26(1) proclaims that ‘[e]veryone has the right to education’, which must be read in conjunction with Article 2, which prohibits discrimination in the enjoyment of the rights recognised in the Universal Declaration on the grounds of ‘race, colour, sex, language, religion, political or other opinion, national or social origin, property, birth or other status’. 9 Eleven years later the United Nations General Assembly adopted the non-binding Declaration of the Rights of the Child 1959 , 10 which more directly affirmed the disabled child’s right to special education, with Paragraph 5 thereof stating that ‘[t]he child who is physically, mentally or socially handicapped shall be given the special treatment, education and care required by his particular condition’. 11

The first time a human right to education was recognised by the United Nations in legally binding treaty format occurred when the General Assembly adopted on 16 December 1966 the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights
12 (ICESCR). Article 13(1) thereof recites that ‘[t]he States Parties to the present Covenant recognize the right of everyone to education’, that ‘education shall be directed to the full development of the human personality and the sense of its dignity’ and that ‘education shall enable all persons to participate effectively in a free society’. 13 That the right to education extends to persons with disabilities is made clear not only by the use of the word ‘everyone’ but by the reference in Article 2(2) of the ICESCR to the guarantee undertaken by States Parties concerning the enjoyment of the rights contained in the Covenant without discrimination on several enumerated grounds including ‘or other status’. Nevertheless, the United Nations and various non-governmental organisations were not content with such broadly stated principles, which lacked a specific contextual application to persons with disabilities. At its 1968 International Congress in Jerusalem, the International League of Societies for the Mentally Handicapped proclaimed a Declaration of General and Special Rights of the Mentally Retarded. A consensus emerged among non-governmental organisations that specific declarations should complement universal and general declarations and conventions. Specifically defined and tailored rights of persons with disabilities contained in the former were in addition to, and not in lieu of, general human rights contained in the latter (Herr, 1980). This appears to have been the driving force behind the promulgation by the United Nations of the Declaration on the Rights of Mentally Retarded Persons, proclaimed by the United Nations General Assembly in Resolution 2856 (XXVI) of 20 December 1971, and the Declaration on the Rights of Disabled Persons, proclaimed by the General Assembly in Resolution 3447 (XXX) of 9 December 1975.

Although the 1971 and 1975 Declarations were not legally binding as a matter of international or municipal law, they did have powers of moral and political suasion, which were used effectively by lobby groups in the 1970s and 1980s to secure important national policy changes. 14 Both the 1971 and 1975 Declarations were underpinned by a desire to assist mentally retarded and disabled persons to develop their abilities in various fields and to promote their integration as far as possible in normal life and society. Both Declarations sought to elaborate upon earlier human rights standards in the form of a set of minimum guidelines to inform national policy-making, and to provide a firmer foundation for the international evolution of even more detailed (and eventually binding) standards. Paragraph 2 of the Declaration on the Rights of Mentally Retarded Persons 1971 stated that ‘[t]he mentally retarded person has a right to such education, training, rehabilitation and guidance as will enable him to develop his ability and maximum potential’. The Declaration on the Rights of Disabled Persons 1975 builds upon the 1971 Declaration. It prescribes in somewhat more detail the entitlements of disabled persons to measures that will ‘enable them to become as self-reliant as possible’ (Paragraph 5). Paragraph 6 of the 1975 Declaration recognises the right of disabled persons to ‘education, vocational training and rehabilitation, aid, counselling, placement services and other services which will enable them to develop their capabilities and skills to the maximum and will hasten the processes of social integration or reintegration’.

sec.title: The post-declaratory framework of programmatic and aspirational principles
sec.p: The importance of the integration of the disabled person within the community was reaffirmed by the Conference on the Legal Protection of the Rights of the Child held in Warsaw, Poland, in January 1979. Principle 7 of the Official Statement of Principles adopted by the Conference articulated the view that, ‘[a]lthough it is desirable to provide special educational facilities for children who are exceptional either in their talents or in their handicaps, it is important that their education should, so far as possible, be integrated with that of other children’ (Stone, 1979). This approach reflected that taken by UNESCO in its adoption of the Revised Recommendation concerning Technical and Vocational Education 1974, which suggested that vocational and technical education should be available to disadvantaged and disabled persons in a manner which caters for their needs and facilitates an easier integration into society. 15

The 1980s witnessed a renaissance in the development of the rights of persons with disabilities, including their educational rights. In 1976, the United Nations General Assembly had designated 1981 as the International Year of Disabled Persons (IYDP). The authorising resolution 16 declared ‘full participation and equality’ as the year’s central theme. It set down a number of objectives to be carried out during the IYDP, including the promotion of ‘efforts to provide disabled people with proper assistance, training, care and guidance’, the education of the public concerning the rights of disabled persons, and the implementation of the 1971 and 1975 Declarations. The Advisory Committee on the IYDP issued recommendations on measures that UN Member States might adopt, and urged the review of existing legislation ‘to eliminate possible discriminatory practices regarding the education and employment of disabled persons’. 17

disp-quote.p: Societies sometimes cater only to people who are in full possession of all their physical and mental faculties. They have to recognize the fact that there will always be a number of people with impairments and disabilities, and that societies have to identify and remove obstacles to their full participation. Thus, whenever pedagogically possible, education should take place in the ordinary school system. (See the second paragraph of the section entitled ‘Equalization of Opportunities’).

sec.p: Accordingly, in order to achieve a policy of striving towards equalising educational opportunities available to persons with disabilities, their education should, as far as possible, take place in the general school system, 18 and laws concerning compulsory education should include children with all ranges of disabilities, including the most severely disabled. 19 Significantly, however, the WPA acknowledged that, if, for some reason, the facilities of the general school system are inadequate for some uniquely or severely disabled children, schooling for these children should then be provided for an appropriate period of time in special facilities and programmes which can offer a quality of education equal to that of the general school system. Whether within an integrated or individualised and specialised teaching environment, the WPA urged the development of ‘individualized’ educational services ‘based on the assessed needs mutually agreed upon by authorities, administrators, parents and disabled students and leading to clearly stated curriculum goals and short term objectives which are regularly reviewed and where necessary revised’ (See the third paragraph of the section entitled ‘Education and Training’ in ‘Proposals for the Implementation of the World Programme of Action concerning Disabled Persons’). Indeed, in discussing the human rights of children with disabilities under the Convention on the Rights of the Child 1989 , 20 the Committee on the Rights of the Child has subsequently observed in the context of the pursuit of a quality education:

disp-quote.p: [a]s children with disabilities are very different from each other, parents, teachers and other specialized professionals have to help each individual child to develop his or her.…skills of communication, language, interaction, orientation and problem-solving which best fit the potential of this child. 21

sec.p: A collegial effort in support of a tailored and individualised learning programme is required.

The international community sought to build on the momentum generated by the WPA when the Global Meeting of Experts to Review the Implementation of the WPA concerning Disabled Persons at the Mid-Point of the United Nations Decade of Disabled Persons was held at Stockholm, Sweden, in 1987. That Meeting recommended that the UN General Assembly convene a special conference to draft an international convention on the elimination of all forms of discrimination against persons with disabilities, to be ratified by States by the end of the Decade in 1992. Despite two attempts by the General Assembly at its forty-second and forty-fourth sessions to settle on a draft of the proposed convention, no consensus could be reached on the suitability of such a convention. 22

sec.title: The Convention on the Rights of the Child 1989
sec.p: Notwithstanding this setback, the United Nations did succeed shortly thereafter in developing the most comprehensive legally binding international human rights norms pertaining to the rights of the disabled child when the General Assembly adopted the Convention on the Rights of the Child 1989 on 20 November 1989. 23 The Convention explicitly prohibits disability-based discrimination 24 and requires States Parties to take special measures to ensure the rights of children with disabilities. The first three sub-articles of Article 23 relate specifically to children with disabilities and read as follows:

disp-quote.p: States Parties recognize that a mentally or physically disabled child should enjoy a full and decent life, in conditions which ensure dignity, promote self-reliance, and facilitate the child’s active participation in the community.

States Parties recognize the right of the disabled child to special care and shall encourage and ensure the extension, subject to available resources, to the eligible child and those responsible for his or her care, of assistance for which application is made and which is appropriate to the child’s condition and to the circumstances of the parents or others caring for the child.

Recognizing the special needs of a disabled child, assistance extended in accordance with paragraph 2 shall be provided free of charge, whenever possible, taking into account the financial resources of the parents or others caring for the child, and shall be designed to ensure that the disabled child has effective access to and receives education, training, health care services, rehabilitation services, preparation for employment and recreation opportunities in a manner conducive to the child’s achieving the fullest possible social integration and individual development, including his or her cultural and spiritual development.

sec.p: Like the previous instruments already referred to, Article 23 emphasises social integration and individual development. It does succeed in enhancing the legal protection of the rights of disabled children as, prior to the adoption of the Convention on the Rights of the Child, there existed relatively few binding international standards in this area. 25 Nevertheless, several deficiencies can be identified. First, the combined effect of sub-articles (2) and (3) of Article 23 is such that the disabled child’s right to education is subject to available State resources and shall be provided free of charge ‘whenever possible, taking into account the financial resources of the parents or others caring for the child’. A revised Polish draft of what is now Article 23, supported by Canada and the USSR, had unsuccessfully proposed that the special educational needs of disabled children should be provided free of charge. 26 Second, as one leading commentator in the children’s rights field has observed, it is unfortunate that the Convention on the Rights of the Child fails to impose on States Parties a legal obligation either to promote or to deliver pre-school educational services (Van Bueren, 1995: 359). Through the combined operation of Articles 2(1) and 28(1) of the Convention, a disabled child has an equal right of access to education only as from the primary school level. 27 As the same commentator has pointed out, pre-school education is important for children with disabilities, as it can be used for the early identification of impairment or learning difficulties and as a method for involving parents in the educational process (Van Bueren, 1995: 359). Likewise the Committee on the Rights of the Child, the treaty-monitoring body operating under the Convention on the Rights of the Child, has recognised the importance of early childhood education in the following terms:

disp-quote.p: Early childhood education is of particular relevance for children with disabilities as often their disabilities and special needs are first recognized in these institutions. Early intervention is of utmost importance to help children to develop their full potential. If a child is identified as having a disability or developmental delay at an early stage, the child has much better opportunities to benefit from early childhood education which should be designed to respond to her or his individual needs. 28

sec.p: Apart from Article 23, Articles 28 and 29 of the Convention on the Rights of the Child 1989 address the human right to, and objectives of, education in a general way with a scope of application covering both disabled and non-disabled children alike. 29 Article 28 essentially ensures to all children, on the bases of non-discrimination and equality of opportunity, the right to education, which includes a compulsory and free primary education, access to general and vocational secondary education, and access to higher education on the basis of capacity. Pursuant to Article 29, the child’s education is to be directed to, inter alia, the development of the child’s personality, talents and mental and physical abilities to their fullest potential as well as the child’s preparation for responsible life in a free society. 30 Thus, for the purposes of ascertaining the substance and scope of application of the human right to education secured for children with disabilities under the Convention on the Rights of the Child 1989 , it will be necessary to have recourse to Articles 23, 28 and 29 in combination with Article 2(1).

The UN Committee on the Rights of the Child has had occasion to make observations on the educational rights of children with disabilities in its General Comment No 9 (2006) The Rights of Children with Disabilities. 31 The Committee has stated that children with disabilities have the same right to education as all other children and enjoy this right without any discrimination and on the basis of equal opportunity under the Convention. The Convention also implicitly recognises the need for modification to school practices and for training of regular teachers to prepare them to teach children with diverse abilities and ensure that they achieve positive educational outcomes. 32 In order to fully exercise their right to education, the Committee has urged the removal of communicational and physical barriers from schools as well as the training of teachers in appropriate languages and other forms of communication. Also recommended is the provision of appropriate and accessible teaching materials, equipment and assistive devices which States Parties to the Convention on the Rights of the Child 1989 should provide to the maximum extent of available resources. 33 The Committee has further advocated that education for career development and vocational skills should also be included in the school curriculum for children with disabilities during the years of compulsory education. In the Committee’s view, the development of career awareness and vocational skills as early as possible enables children to make better choices later in life in terms of employment. In those countries where compulsory education does not go beyond the elementary school years, vocational training beyond elementary school should, in the Committee’s view, be mandatory for children with disabilities. 34

sec.title: Standard Rules on the Equalization of Opportunities for Persons with Disabilities 1993
sec.p: The World Conference on Human Rights held in Vienna, Austria, in June 1993 reaffirmed in Paragraph 63 of its Programme of Action that:

disp-quote.p: all human rights and fundamental freedoms are universal and thus unreservedly include persons with disabilities. Every person is born equal and has the same rights to education and work. Any discriminatory treatment of a disabled person is therefore a violation of his or her rights. The World Conference on Human Rights calls on Governments to adopt legislation to assure access to these rights for disabled persons.

sec.p: In Paragraph 65 of its Programme of Action, the World Conference called on the United Nations General Assembly ‘to adopt the draft standard rules on the equalization of opportunities for persons with disabilities’ which had emerged from the World Programme of Action concerning Disabled Persons and the General Assembly had endorsed in 1982.

The United Nations General Assembly did indeed heed the World Conference’s call by adopting in its Resolution 48/96 of 20 December 1993 the Standard Rules on the Equalization of Opportunities for Persons with Disabilities
35 and requested UN Member States to apply the Rules in developing national disability programmes. After the unsuccessful attempts by the General Assembly to agree on an international convention on the elimination of all forms of discrimination against persons with disabilities, it was agreed to formulate the non-binding Standard Rules on the basis of experience gained during the United Nations Decade of Disabled Persons (1983–1992) and the World Programme of Action concerning Disabled Persons. The international human rights instruments previously referred to in the text of this article constitute the political, legal and moral foundations of the Standard Rules. Their purpose is to ensure that girls, boys, women and men with disabilities may exercise the same rights as others. Although the Standard Rules are not legally binding, 36 they are founded on a strong moral and political commitment on the part of UN Member States to take action for the equalisation of opportunities 37 for persons with disabilities, and provide a basis for mutual technical and economic co-operation. From the standpoint of persons with disabilities and their representative organisations, the Rules offer policy-making leverage and an advocacy platform.

Rule 6 of the Standard Rules comprises nine sub-rules which directly concern the educational entitlements of persons with disabilities. Since they are the most detailed norms yet to be developed in this particular context, it is appropriate to set them out in full 38 as follows:

disp-quote.p: Rule 6. Education

States should recognize the principle of equal primary, secondary and tertiary educational opportunities for children, youth and adults with disabilities, in integrated settings. They should ensure that the education of persons with disabilities is an integral part of the educational system.

General educational authorities are responsible for the education of persons with disabilities in integrated settings. Education for persons with disabilities should form an integral part of national educational planning, curriculum development and school organization.

Education in mainstream schools presupposes the provision of interpreter and other appropriate support services. Adequate accessibility and support services, designed to meet the needs of persons with different disabilities, should be provided.
Parent groups and organizations of persons with disabilities should be involved in the education process at all levels. 39
In States where education is compulsory it should be provided to girls and boys with all kinds and all levels of disabilities, including the most severe.
Special attention should be given in the following areas:
Very young children with disabilities;
Pre-school children with disabilities; 40
Adults with disabilities, particularly women.
To accommodate educational provisions for persons with disabilities in the mainstream, States should:
Have a clearly stated policy, understood and accepted at the school level and by the wider community;
Allow for curriculum flexibility, addition and adaptation;
Provide for quality materials, ongoing teacher training and support teachers.

Integrated education and community-based programmes should be seen as complementary approaches in providing cost-effective education and training for persons with disabilities. National community-based programmes should encourage communities to use and develop their resources to provide local education to persons with disabilities.

sec.p: Rule 6 of the Standard Rules is unremarkable to the extent that it reaffirms the principle of equality of educational opportunity for disabled children and the delivery of that education in most cases within an integrated mainstream setting. These entitlements were secured, as we have just seen, by Articles 2 and 23 of the Convention on the Rights of the Child 1989 . Several other features of Rule 6, however, are noteworthy. First, Rule 6 applies to all persons with disabilities. Second, Rule 6(3) innovatively and rightfully recognises the constructive stakeholder involvement of parents, advocacy and representative organisations and persons with disabilities themselves in the educational process. Third, unlike the Convention on the Rights of the Child 1989 , Rule 6(5) singles out for special attention pre-school children with disabilities. Fourth, Rule 6(7) introduces the notion that the education and training of persons with disabilities should be ‘cost-effective’. This differs from the resource-dependent stipulations in Article 23 of the Convention on the Rights of the Child 1989 . In its Resolution 49/153 of 1994, the United Nations General Assembly urged all governments to implement the Standard Rules and welcomed the appointment of a Special Rapporteur on Disability to monitor their implementation, to advance the status of persons with disabilities throughout the world, and to submit reports to the Commission for Social Development. The Special Rapporteur on Disability of the United Nations Commission for Social Development was first appointed in 1994.

sec.title: The Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities 2006
sec.p:
Nearly two decades elapsed until the initiative first proposed by the Global Meeting of Experts to Review the Implementation of the World Programme of Action concerning Disabled Persons, that the United Nations adopt an international convention on the elimination of all forms of discrimination against persons with disabilities, was realised. On 13 December 2006, the UN General Assembly adopted the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.
41 It is clear from the Preamble to the Convention that the norms prescribed in the operative text of the Convention are informed to a significant degree by the legal principles and policy guidelines contained in the World Programme of Action concerning Disabled Persons, the Standard Rules on the Equalization of Opportunities for Persons with Disabilities and the Convention on the Rights of the Child 1989 .
42 The overarching purpose of the Disabilities Convention, as made explicit in its Article 1, is ‘to promote, protect and ensure the full and equal enjoyment of all human rights and fundamental freedoms by all persons with disabilities, and to promote respect for their inherent dignity’.

The specific objectives of the Convention are the further equalisation of opportunities for persons with disabilities and the elimination of all forms of discrimination against them. Concerning the latter objective, ‘discrimination on the basis of disability’ is defined in Article 2 to mean ‘any distinction, exclusion or restriction on the basis of disability which has the purpose or effect of impairing or nullifying the recognition, enjoyment or exercise, on an equal basis with others, of all human rights [including] all forms of discrimination, including denial of reasonable accommodation’. It is clear that the use of the phrase ‘which has the purpose or effect’ in that definition is intended to catch both direct discrimination and indirect discrimination whereby, in relation to the latter, the policy or practice, although neutral on its face and not blatantly discriminatory, is nonetheless discriminatory in its effect and/or application. The term ‘reasonable accommodation’ is defined in turn in Article 2 to mean ‘necessary and appropriate modification and adjustments not imposing a disproportionate or undue burden, where needed in a particular case, to ensure to persons with disabilities the enjoyment or exercise on an equal basis with others of all human rights.’ 43 The general principles upon which the Disabilities Convention is based include non-discrimination, equality of opportunity, accessibility, acceptance of persons with disabilities, full and effective participation and inclusion in society, and respect for the freedom to make one’s own choices and independence. 44 The principle of accessibility in the educational context is reinforced by preambular paragraph (v) of the Convention, which explicitly recognises the importance of accessibility to education and information in enabling persons with disabilities to fully enjoy all human rights. Concerning the freedom to make one’s own choices, preambular paragraph (o) asserts the wisdom of such persons having ‘the opportunity to be actively involved in decision-making processes about policies and programmes’ which directly affect and concern them.

In terms of the general obligations assumed under the Disabilities Convention, States Parties undertake to ensure, pursuant to Article 4, ‘the full realization of all human rights. for all persons with disabilities without discrimination of any kind on the basis of disability’. To that end, States Parties undertake, inter alia, to adopt appropriate legislative, administrative and other measures for the implementation of the Convention rights and the elimination of disability-based discrimination. 45 In relation to economic, social and cultural rights, which include the human right to education, each State Party ‘undertakes to take measures to the maximum of its available resources, and, where needed, within the framework of international cooperation, with a view to achieving progressively the full realization of these rights’. 46 As is the case with the general right to education recognised by Article 13 of the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights 1966 , implementation of the human right to education for persons with disabilities is progressive in nature and requires positive State action. States Parties to the ICESCR are also obligated to improve the existing conditions concerning education to the maximum of their available resources. This is made clear by Article 2(1) of the ICESCR, which provides that ‘[e]ach State Party undertakes to take steps, individually and through international assistance and co-operation, to the maximum of its available resources, with a view to achieving progressively the full realization of the rights recognized in the present Covenant by all appropriate means.’ These treaty provisions have particularly in mind the economies of developing States, whose financial resources and revenue are comparatively limited. In conceding a margin of appreciation, as it were, the UN Committee on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, the ICESCR monitoring body, has rejected the notion that the implementation of these rights, including the right to education, may be deferred indefinitely. The Committee has insisted that the obligation to ‘take steps’ is a serious and solemn one and that the poverty of States is not a valid reason for inaction, since diligent governments should solicit resources from the international community (Thornberry, 1994: 10, 11). The Committee has stated:

disp-quote.p: … while the full realization of the relevant rights may be achieved progressively, steps towards that goal must be taken within a reasonably short time after the Covenant’s entry into force for the States concerned. Such steps should be deliberate, concrete and targeted as clearly as possible towards meeting the obligations recognized in the Covenant. 47

sec.p:
The interpretative guidelines of The Limburg Principles on the Implementation of the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights
48 specifically relating to Article 2(1) of the ICESCR are also informative in terms of the implementation of the obligation assumed by States Parties under Article 13 thereof. Principle 21 states:

disp-quote.p: The obligation ‘to achieve progressively the full realization of the rights’ requires States parties to move as expeditiously as possible towards the realization of the rights. Under no circumstances shall this be interpreted as implying for States the right to defer indefinitely efforts to ensure full realization. On the contrary all States parties have the obligation to begin immediately to take steps to fulfil their obligations under the Covenant.

sec.p: Principles 23 and 25 of The Limburg Principles also offer little comfort to developing States. Principle 23 provides that ‘[t]he obligation of progressive achievement exists independently of the increase in resources; it requires effective use of resources available’. Principle 25 acknowledges that ‘States parties are obligated, regardless of the level of economic development, to ensure respect for minimum subsistence rights for all’. It is arguable that fundamental education – literacy, numeracy and basic life skills – would be considered a minimum subsistence right and, as such, must be given sufficient priority in terms of the governmental allocation of finite resources. It is submitted that these observations of the Committee on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights and The Limburg Principles should apply with equal force and relevance to persons with disabilities in the educational context and to the resource-dependent obligation assumed by States Parties under Article 4(2) of the Disabilities Convention. This is critical in light of the fact that the majority of persons with disabilities reside in developing countries. 49

Article 24 of the Disabilities Convention is the operative provision of the Convention which deals specifically with education. In light of the importance of its substantive provisions and their centrality to the subject of this article, Article 24 is set out in full as follows:

disp-quote.p: States Parties recognize the right of persons with disabilities to education. 50 With a view to realizing this right without discrimination and on the basis of equal opportunity, States Parties shall ensure an inclusive education system at all levels and life long learning directed to:
The full development of human potential and sense of dignity and self-worth, and the strengthening of respect for human rights, fundamental freedoms and human diversity;
The development by persons with disabilities of their personality, talents and creativity, as well as their mental and physical abilities, to their fullest potential; 51
Enabling persons with disabilities to participate effectively in a free society.
In realizing this right, States Parties shall ensure that:

a. Persons with disabilities are not excluded from the general education system on the basis of disability, and that children with disabilities are not excluded from free and compulsory primary education, or from secondary education, on the basis of disability;
b. Persons with disabilities can access an inclusive, quality and free primary education and secondary education on an equal basis with others in the communities in which they live;
c. Reasonable accommodation of the individual’s requirements is provided;
d. Persons with disabilities receive the support required, within the general education system, to facilitate their effective education;
e. Effective individualized support measures are provided in environments that maximize academic and social development, consistent with the goal of full inclusion.

States Parties shall enable persons with disabilities to learn life and social development skills to facilitate their full and equal participation in education and as members of the community. To this end, States Parties shall take appropriate measures, including:

Facilitating the learning of Braille, alternative script, augmentative and alternative modes, means and formats of communication and orientation and mobility skills, and facilitating peer support and mentoring;
Facilitating the learning of sign language and the promotion of the linguistic identity of the deaf community; 52

Ensuring that the education of persons, and in particular children, who are blind, deaf or deafblind, is delivered in the most appropriate languages and modes and means of communication for the individual, and in environments which maximize academic and social development.

In order to help ensure the realization of this right, States Parties shall take appropriate measures to employ teachers, including teachers with disabilities, who are qualified in sign language and/or Braille, and to train professionals and staff who work at all levels of education. Such training shall incorporate disability awareness and the use of appropriate augmentative and alternative modes, means and formats of communication, educational techniques and materials to support persons with disabilities. 53

States Parties shall ensure that persons with disabilities are able to access general tertiary education, vocational training, adult education and lifelong learning without discrimination and on an equal basis with others. To this end, States Parties shall ensure that reasonable accommodation is provided to persons with disabilities.

sec.p: The clear thrust of Article 24 is towards an inclusive education system for persons with disabilities as well as reasonable accommodation of their individual requirements. During the deliberations of the Working Group, different approaches were taken in articulating the relationship between the provision of specialist education services and the general education system. Some members of the Working Group considered that the education of children with disabilities in the general education system should be the rule, and the provision of specialist education services the exception. Other members considered that specialist education services should not only be provided where the general education system is inadequate, but rather be made available at all times without a presumption that one approach was more desirable than the other. The overall intent appears to be to ensure that the general education system and specialist education services are not mutually exclusive options, and that there is a range of intermediate options available. Some members of the Working Group, for example, emphasised the need for deaf and blind children to be allowed to be educated in their own groups and there was general support at the Sixth Session that children with particularly debilitating disabilities, such as blind, deaf and deafblind children, may need to commence their learning in an environment that is more specific and tailored to their needs in order to allow them to subsequently gain maximum benefit from a fully inclusive general education system. 54

sec.title: Regional recognition of the educational rights of the disabled
sec.p:
The African, American and European human rights systems have all recognised in treaty form the educational entitlements of persons with disabilities. Article 100(d) of the Charter of the Organization of American States 1948
55 obliges the Inter-American Council for Education, Science, and Culture to ‘encourage the adoption of special educational programs directed toward integrating all sectors of the population into their respective national cultures’. Special education programmes are also mentioned in the Additional Protocol to the American Convention on Human Rights in the Area of Economic, Social and Cultural Rights 1988 . 56 States Parties to the Additional Protocol recognise in Article 13(3)(e) thereof that ‘[p]rograms of special education should be established for the handicapped, so as to provide special instruction and training to persons with physical disabilities or mental deficiencies’.

The African Charter on Human and Peoples’ Rights 1981
57 is less explicit. Article 18(4) thereof simply states that ‘[t]he aged and the disabled shall also have the right to special measures of protection in keeping with their physical or moral needs’. As far as children with disabilities are concerned, Article 13 of the African Charter on the Rights and Welfare of the Child 1990
58 contains somewhat more detail. Pursuant to Article 13(2), States Parties ‘shall ensure that the disabled child has effective access to training, preparation for employment and recreation opportunities in a manner conducive to the child achieving the fullest possible social integration [and] development’. 59 Within the Council of Europe, the rights of the disabled to vocational guidance and training are secured by Articles 9 and 15 respectively of the European Social Charter 1961 .
60 Article 15(1) obliges the Contracting Parties to take adequate measures for the provision of training facilities and specialised institutions with a view to ensuring the effective exercise of the right of the physically or mentally disabled to vocational training and rehabilitation.

The European Commission on Human Rights has dealt with several applications concerning placement of children with learning difficulties in special schools. In one case 61 the parents complained that this was contrary to their wishes and, accordingly, contravened Article 2 of Protocol 1 to the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms, 62 which states:

disp-quote.p: No person shall be denied the right to education. In the exercise of any functions which it assumes in relation to education and teaching, the State shall respect the right of parents to ensure such education and teaching in conformity with their own religious and philosophical convictions.

sec.p: The Commission held that Article 2 required a balance to be struck between the expressed wishes of the parents and the disabled child’s right to have as effective an education as possible. In the Commission’s view, ‘there must be a wide measure of discretion left to the appropriate authorities as to how to make the best use possible of the resources available to them in the interests of disabled children generally’. 63 The Commission’s decision reflects, in part, the margin of appreciation it was willing to accord the State in the context of resource-intensive special education programmes competing with other social welfare claims in the context of a limited governmental budget.

sec.title: Inclusive or individualised education: an either/or or complementary approach?
sec.p: Special education is essentially education for persons suffering from physical or mental impairments or other disabilities. Such education can range from tuition in an integrated setting in a classroom within a mainstream school, through placement in a special unit within a mainstream school, to enrolment in a special school. The concepts of integration and normalisation were introduced after the Second World War in recognition of the growing awareness of the capabilities of persons with disabilities. 64 Arguments supporting integration and ‘mainstreaming’ include egalitarianism and economic arguments concerning the untapped productive potential of disabled persons and the financial and opportunity costs of maintaining in specialised institutions those who could be self-sufficient and productive (Neal, 1982: 150). Advocates for specialised education, on the other hand, point to its ability to deliver an education more tailored and targeted to meet the special needs of disabled persons. In a study entitled Review of the Present Situation of Special Education published in 1988, UNESCO lamented the absence of national education planning and programmes addressing the needs and entitlements of children with disabilities and concluded that the responsibility for special education should fall within the ambit of the national educational system, arguing against the establishment of two separate systems (UNESCO, 1988).

During the drafting of Article 23 of the Convention on the Rights of the Child 1989 , the debate touched upon but did not consider in any detail whether the best interests of disabled children would be served by the establishment of special schools for them, or by fully integrated schooling (Van Bueren, 1995: 359). At best the Convention leaves the matter open; at worst, its position is ambiguous. On the one hand, Article 23(3) opens with the clause ‘[r]ecognizing the special needs of a disabled child’. On the other hand, Article 23(3) later states that the disabled child is to receive education and training “’in a manner conducive to the child’s achieving the fullest possible social integration and individual development’. In any event, the Committee on the Rights of the Child, the Convention’s monitoring body, has considered the meaning and requirements of inclusive education in the context of persons with disabilities in its General Comment No 9 (2006) The Rights of Children with Disabilities.
65 The Committee has stated that inclusive education 66 should be the goal of educating children with disabilities. At its core, the concept of inclusive education comprises ‘a set of values, principles and practices that seeks meaningful, effective, and quality education for all students, that does justice to the diversity of learning conditions and requirements not only of children with disabilities, but for all students’. 67 The Committee has adopted with approval the following definition of ‘inclusion’, formulated by UNESCO in 2005:

disp-quote.p: Inclusion is seen as a process of addressing and responding to the diversity of needs of all learners through increasing participation in learning, cultures and communities, and reducing exclusion within and from education. It involves changes and modifications in content, approaches, structures and strategies, with a common vision which covers all children of the appropriate age range and a conviction that it is the responsibility of the regular system to educate all children. Inclusion is concerned with the identification and removal of barriers.

sec.p: Guthrie and Waldeck have described inclusiveness in education in the disability context in the following passage:

disp-quote.p: Inclusiveness in education is a rights-based approach to education, i.e. the right of a student to have equal access to education. Its proponents argue that inclusion is concerned with the protection of human rights for all students. Inclusion represents a philosophical shift from related practices such as ‘mainstreaming’ and ‘integration’ where the focus is on placing students with disabilities in mainstream settings with the aspiration that all students would benefit from the experience. Inclusion places a focus on the quality of the participation of the student with disabilities and involves welcoming students with disabilities as full members of the group and values that student for their contribution. In the context of disability discrimination, inclusiveness embraces the notion that separation of students by reason of differences arising out of their disability is detrimental not only to the student with a disability but also to all other participants in the education institution as well.

sec.p: The Committee on the Rights of the Child has essentially taken a ‘functional capacity’ approach to inclusive education for disabled children. The form and degree of inclusion are to be determined by the educational needs of each individual child, since the education of some children requires support and resources which may not be readily available in the regular school system. 68 The Committee has emphasised that the extent of inclusion within the general education system will vary and that ‘[a] continuum of services and programme options must be maintained in circumstances where fully inclusive education is not feasible to achieve in the immediate future’. 69 Inclusion may therefore range from full-time placement of all students with disabilities into one regular classroom to placement into the regular classroom with varying degrees of inclusion, including a certain portion of special education. 70 The Committee has also rightly acknowledged that inclusive education extends beyond the important question of how students with disabilities can best be included in the classroom and in programmes. To fully implement inclusive education, the training and supportive attitudes of teachers and auxiliary staff are an integral component in the process, as they are responsible for much of the daily ‘on the ground’ implementation of inclusive education policies (Guthrie and Waldeck, 2008: 142). 71 Close co-operation between special educators and regular teachers and appropriate revision of the school curricula will also be required. 72

The views of the Committee on the Rights of the Child on the provision of inclusive education to disabled children were published in 2006 and were no doubt significantly influenced by both the Standard Rules on the Equalization of Opportunities for Persons with Disabilities which were adopted by the UN General Assembly in 1993 and by the then imminent adoption of the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities by the General Assembly, which occurred on 13 December 2006. Rule 6 of the Standard Rules generally espouses a philosophy of ‘integrated education’ of persons with disabilities. Sub-rules (8) and (9) of Rule 6 of the Standard Rules deal specifically with special education, respectively providing as follows:

disp-quote.p: In situations where the general school system does not yet adequately meet the needs of all persons with disabilities, special education may be considered. It should be aimed at preparing students for education in the general school system. The quality of such education should reflect the same standards and ambitions as general education and should be closely linked to it. At a minimum, students with disabilities should be afforded the same portion of educational resources as students without disabilities. States should aim for the gradual integration of special education services into mainstream education. It is acknowledged that in some circumstances special education may currently be considered to be the most appropriate form of education for some students with disabilities.

Owing to the particular communication needs of deaf and deaf/blind persons, their education may be more suitably provided in schools for such persons or special classes and units in mainstream schools. At the initial stage, in particular, special attention needs to be focused on culturally sensitive instruction that will result in effective communication skills and maximum independence for people who are deaf or deaf/blind.

sec.p: Sub-rules (8) and (9) thus establish integration as the rule rather than the exception. Special education is considered as preparing students at an early stage for mainstream education and as a temporary and transitional expedient pending economic and material restructuring. The trend, however, is towards the gradual integration of special educational services into mainstream education. There may be one exception, however. Pending the development of new technologies and techniques, special education may continue to be the only viable option for the most severely disabled, including the deaf and the deaf/blind. 73

As noted above, the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities 2006 contains an explicit commitment towards the goal of inclusive education. 74 Preambular paragraph (m) of the Convention recognises ‘the valued contributions made by persons with disabilities to their communities, and that full participation by persons with disabilities will result in their enhanced sense of belonging.’ Persons with disabilities are also members of society and have the right to remain within their local communities. As the Committee on the Rights of the Child has observed, it is crucial that education of a child with a disability includes making sure that the child feels that he or she is respected by others as a human being. Inclusion of the child with a disability in a group of classroom children can show the child that he or she has a recognised identity and belongs to the community of learners. 75 The Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities will be guided in its deliberations by the Standard Rules and the pronouncements of the Committee on the Rights of the Child in the process of interpreting and elaborating upon the substantive provisions of the Disabilities Convention concerning the provision of inclusive education to persons with disabilities. The current position would appear to be that inclusive education and individualised education for persons with disabilities are not mutually exclusive, but rather complementary, options, except for the most serious cases of disability.

sec.title: The Australian Disability Discrimination Act 1992
sec.p:
Australia has ratified most United Nations human rights conventions, including the Convention on the Rights of the Child 1989 and the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities 2006 .
76 In 1992 the Commonwealth of Australia enacted the Disability Discrimination Act, which has set a comprehensive national benchmark in relation to the prohibition of disability-based discrimination. The statute also represents a significant instrument for social change in so far as it attempts to bring persons with disabilities into the economic, social and cultural mainstream of Australian society. The objects of the Act include, inter alia, the elimination of disability-based discrimination in the areas of work, accommodation, education, access to premises, clubs and sport as well as the provision of goods, facilities and services. The Act is also designed ‘to ensure, as far as practicable, that persons with disabilities have the same rights to equality before the law as the rest of the community’. 77 In stark contrast to the brief and non-exhaustive definition of ‘persons with disabilities’ as contained in Article 1 of the Disabilities Convention, Section 4 of the Act prescribes what appears to be a comprehensive and exhaustive definition of ‘disability’, which is as follows:

disp-quote.p: ‘disability’, in relation to a person, means:
total or partial loss of the person’s bodily or mental functions; or
total or partial loss of a part of the body; or
the presence in the body of organisms causing disease or illness; or
the presence in the body of organisms capable of causing disease or illness; or
the malfunction, malformation or disfigurement of a part of the person’s body; or
a disorder or malfunction that results in the person learning differently from a person without the disorder or malfunction; or
a disorder, illness or disease that affects a person’s thought processes, perception of reality, emotions or judgment or that results in disturbed behaviour;
and includes a disability that:
presently exists; or
previously existed but no longer exists; or
may exist in the future (including because of a genetic predisposition to that disability); or
is imputed to a person.
To avoid doubt, a disability that is otherwise covered by this definition includes behaviour that is a symptom or manifestation of the disability.

sec.p:
The Commonwealth Parliament has thus taken a broad and purposive approach in defining the term ‘disability’, particularly in relation to manifestation listed in (g) and imputation listed in (k). In relation to manifestation of disturbed behaviour, the High Court of Australia has taken an expansive approach to the interpretation of the term ‘disability’. In Purvis v State of New South Wales (Department of Education and Training)
78 the High Court held that a disability as defined in Section 4 of the Act not only includes the underlying disorder but extends to the behavioural manifestations thereof. 79

The Disability Discrimination Act 1992 proscribes both direct and indirect disability discrimination under Sections 5 and 6 respectively. 80 The Act is a legislative recognition that it is not sufficient to treat a person with a disability in the same way as other non-disabled people are treated. The disability may require the person to receive differential treatment through the making of reasonable adjustments to accommodate the disability. Section 5 states:

disp-quote.p: [A] person (the discriminator) discriminates against another person (the aggrieved person) on the ground of a disability of the aggrieved person if, because of the disability, the discriminator treats, or proposes to treat, the aggrieved person less favourably than the discriminator would treat a person without the disability in circumstances that are not materially different.

sec.p: Direct disability discrimination can also occur if a person fails to make reasonable adjustments for the aggrieved person and that failure results in less favourable treatment. 81 According to Section 4, an adjustment is reasonable unless making the adjustment would impose an unjustifiable hardship on the person. Whether an unjustifiable hardship can be made out will depend on all of the relevant circumstances of the particular case, including the nature of the benefit or detriment likely to accrue to, or to be suffered by, any person concerned, 82 the effect of the disability of any person concerned, the financial circumstances of, and the estimated amount of expenditure required to be made by, the person alleging unjustifiable hardship, and the availability of financial and other assistance to that person. 83 The burden of proving a case of unjustifiable hardship lies on the person claiming such hardship. 84 In assessing the adjustments required for a student with disability and whether they would amount to unjustifiable hardship, the education provider must make an individualised investigation by assessing the needs of the individual student in consultation with the student and the student’s parents/associates. 85

Under Section 6(1), indirect disability discrimination occurs where a person (the discriminator) requires, or proposes to require, another person (the aggrieved person) to comply with a requirement or condition which the aggrieved person cannot do because of the disability and the requirement or condition has the effect of disadvantaging persons with the disability. A finding of discrimination will be avoided if the requirement is reasonable, having regard to the circumstances of the case. 86 The burden of proving reasonableness of the requirement or condition will rest with the person who requires the person with the disability to comply with the requirement or condition. 87

Section 22 of the Disability Discrimination Act 1992 is the substantive provision which prohibits disability-based discrimination in the education sector. It is unlawful for an educational authority 88 to discriminate against a person on the ground of the person’s disability, inter alia, by refusing or failing to accept the person’s application for admission as a student, in the conditions on which it is prepared to admit the person as a student, by limiting the student’s access to any benefit provided by the educational authority, by subjecting the student to any detriment, or by developing curricula having a content that will exclude the person with a disability from participation.

The detailed regulation and oversight of disability-based discrimination in the education sector have been delegated to the government ministers responsible, 89 who may, by legislative instrument, 90 formulate disability standards in relation to the areas covered by the Act including education. These standards may cover such matters as reasonable adjustments, strategies to prevent harassment or victimisation of persons with a disability, and unjustifiable hardship. 91 The disability standards enjoy an enhanced status in the sense that it is unlawful for a person to contravene a disability standard. 92 According to Section 34 of the Act, if a person acts in accordance with a disability standard, they are deemed to be acting lawfully and in a non-discriminatory manner and, as such, in compliance with the Act. Thus, in the education sector, Section 34 will effectively exempt education providers from the operation of the unlawful discrimination provisions 93 of the Act, where they can demonstrate compliance with any relevant disability standards concerning education.

sec.title: The Australian Disability Standards for Education 2005
Introduction
sec.p: The Disability Standards for Education (hereinafter referred to as the Education Standards) were formulated by the Commonwealth Attorney-General pursuant to Section 31 of the Disability Discrimination Act 1992 and came into effect on 18 August 2005. 94 The Education Standards establish a framework to ensure that students with disability are provided with sufficient opportunities to realise their full potential through access to, and participation in, education and training on the same basis as other students. The objects of the Standards are explicitly set out in Paragraph 1.3 thereof as follows:

disp-quote.p: to eliminate, as far as possible, discrimination against persons on the ground of disability in the area of education and training; and
to ensure, as far as practicable, that persons with disabilities have the same rights to equality before the law in the area of education and training as the rest of the community; and
to promote recognition and acceptance within the community of the principle that persons with disabilities have the same fundamental rights as the rest of the community.

sec.p: The Education Standards are subordinate legislation and, as such, are subject to, and must remain consistent with, the objects of the Disability Discrimination Act 1992 . The Education Standards represent a comprehensive and proactive clarification and elaboration upon the positive and negative legal obligations imposed by the Act in relation to the education of persons with disabilities. In terms of their scope of application, the Education Standards apply to government and non-government/private education providers 95 in all education sectors – pre-school, 96 school, post-compulsory education and training authorities including vocational education and training, higher education (including universities) and adult and community education – as well as to organisations whose functions include the development and accreditation of curricula and courses used by education authorities. 97

In terms of areas of substantive coverage, the Standards extend to enrolment, participation, curriculum development, accreditation and delivery, student support services, and the elimination of harassment and victimisation. In general terms, an education provider is required to make admission, enrolment and participation decisions on the basis that ‘reasonable adjustments’ will be made where necessary to enable the student with disability to be treated on the same basis as a student without the disability. Nevertheless, only an adjustment which is reasonable in the circumstances is required to be made. As we shall see, even if the adjustment is reasonable, such adjustment is not mandatory if it would cause ‘unjustifiable hardship’ to the education provider.

Prior to the adoption of the Education Standards, the Disability Discrimination Act 1992 did not explicitly specify the types of adjustments required to be undertaken by education providers to negate unlawful discrimination. The Standards now provide guidance in this regard. In terms of the methodology employed in the Standards, each Part begins with a statement of the rights or entitlements of students with disabilities in relation to specific aspects of education and training, followed by the legal obligations or responsibilities of education providers, and concludes with a description of the measures that, upon implementation by the education provider, will be deemed to be evidence of compliance with the legal obligation.

sec.title: Reasonable adjustment
sec.p:
Part 3 of the Education Standards deals with the making of reasonable adjustments by education providers. To the extent that the decision of the High Court of Australia in Purvis v State of New South Wales (Department of Education and Training)
98 refused to read into or infer from the Disability Discrimination Act 1992 the concept of reasonable adjustment, the subsequent amendments to the Act and the Standards themselves have reversed that position. According to Paragraph 3.3, adjustments include a measure or action taken by an education provider that has the effect of assisting a student with a disability in relation to applying for admission or enrolment, in participating in a course or programme, or using facilities or services on the same basis as a student without a disability (including an aid, a facility or a service that the student requires because of the disability). Consistently with the Standard Rules on the Equalization of Opportunities for Persons with Disabilities 1993 and the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities 2006 , 99 the education provider is required to consult the student (or an associate of the student) before making an adjustment for the student.

An adjustment is reasonable if it balances the interests of all affected parties. 100 Unlike the parent Disability Discrimination Act 1992 , the Standards articulate a number of non-exhaustive criteria for determining whether a particular adjustment for a student is reasonable, having regard to the following circumstances and interests:

disp-quote.p: (a) the student’s disability;
(b) the views of the student;
(c) the effect of the adjustment on the student, including the effect on the student’s:
(i) ability to achieve learning outcomes; and
(ii) ability to participate in courses or programs; and
(iii) independence;
(d) the effect of the proposed adjustment on anyone else affected, including the education provider, staff and other students;
(e) the costs and benefits of making the adjustment. 101

sec.p: The Education Standards have foreshadowed that a detailed assessment by an independent expert may be required in order to determine what adjustments are necessary for a student. 102 There is no requirement under the Standards, therefore, to make any adjustment which is assessed to be ‘unreasonable’ through an application of the above-mentioned criteria. If deemed unreasonable, that is the end of the matter and the education provider need take no further action. If, however, the adjustment has been assessed to be reasonable, it is open to the education provider to then raise the defence of unjustifiable hardship. As we shall later see, Paragraph 10.2 of the Standards provides that it is not unlawful for an education provider to fail to comply with a requirement of the Standards if, and to the extent that, compliance would impose unjustifiable hardship on the provider. The concept of unreasonable adjustment is therefore technically different, both temporally and substantively, from the concept of unjustifiable hardship, although some of the criteria used to determine the reasonableness of the adjustment, as listed above, overlap somewhat with the criteria used to determine the issue of unjustifiable hardship under Section 11 of the Disability Discrimination Act 1992 . Guthrie and Waldeck have explained in the following passage the operative contexts of the concepts of ‘reasonable adjustment’ and ‘unjustifiable hardship’ and their possible overlap:

disp-quote.p: [I]f there is non-compliance with an Education Standard the unlawful discrimination provision may be reactivated, so that the defence of unjustifiable hardship may also be relevant. In other words, consideration of these issues is a two-step process. Firstly, does the student with a disability require some form of adjustment to be made to facilities or services from an education provider, and if so is that adjustment reasonable. Secondly, if the adjustment is reasonable but the education provider has not made the adjustment, the provider may have a defence of unjustifiable hardship … [D]espite the apparent separation of these concepts there is likely to be some overlap between the two, particularly as the obligation for reasonable adjustment does require consideration of the cost of any adjustment, which is also a consideration for the defence of unjustifiable hardship. 103

sec.p: Another important issue concerning the making of reasonable adjustments arises in the context of the retention of the academic integrity of the education provider’s courses and programmes. Paragraph 3.4(3) of the Standards provides that, in assessing whether an adjustment to the course or programme is reasonable, the provider is entitled to maintain the academic requirements of that course or programme. As an explanatory note to this provision states, a provider may continue to secure the integrity of its courses and programmes and assessment requirements in order to ensure that those on whom it confers a degree or award can present themselves as having the appropriate knowledge, experience and expertise implicit in the holding of that particular degree or award. 104

sec.title: Enrolment, inclusive education and curriculum standards
sec.p: Part 4 of the Education Standards concerns enrolment issues. The education provider is required to take reasonable steps to ensure that a prospective student is able to seek admission to the institution on the same basis as a prospective student without a disability and without experiencing discrimination. 105 Measures that an education provider may take in compliance with the Standards (and thereby in discharge of its obligations under the Disability Discrimination Act 1992 ) include, inter alia, the designing of enrolment procedures so that a prospective student with a disability can complete them without undue difficulty and ensuring that information about the enrolment processes, entry requirements and choice of courses is accessible to the prospective student.

The concept of inclusive education is codified in Part 5 of the Education Standards relating to standards for participation. The education provider is required under Paragraph 5.2 to take reasonable steps to ensure that the student is able to participate in the course or programme provided by the educational institution on the same basis as a student without a disability and without experiencing discrimination. 106 Demonstrable compliance with these participation standards includes the taking of measures by the education provider to ensure that the course or programme activities are sufficiently flexible for the student with disability to be able to participate in them as well as the provision of additional necessary support to assist in the achievement of learning outcomes. 107 The availability and quantity of such additional support or affirmative action would remain subject to assessment of whether any proposed adjustment would be reasonable in the circumstances (as well as a consideration of unjustifiable hardship if raised by the education provider). If a course or programme necessarily includes an activity in which the student cannot participate (such as an extensive field trip), the education provider should offer to the student an activity that constitutes a reasonable substitute. 108
