Standards for curriculum development, accreditation and delivery are prescribed in Part 6 of the Education Standards. The education provider must take reasonable steps to ensure that the course or programme is designed in such a way that a student with disability is able to participate in learning experiences and assessment on the same basis as a student without a disability and without experiencing discrimination. 109 Suggested implementation measures include ensuring that the curriculum, teaching materials, and assessment and certification requirements are appropriate to the needs of the student, the learning activities take account of the learning capacities and needs of the student, the study materials are made available in an appropriate format, and the learning strategies are adjusted to meet the learning needs of the student through the provision of additional support (such as bridging or enabling courses). 110

sec.title: Support services
sec.p: Support services are especially important for students with disabilities in facilitating their access to education and training. These services include personal or individualised educational support or support for personal and medical care. The education provider must take reasonable steps to ensure that a student with disability is able to access and use support services used by the students of the institution on the same basis as a student without a disability and without experiencing discrimination. 111 If a specialised support service is necessary, the provider must take reasonable steps to facilitate the provision of the service to the student, whether or not that service is offered by the provider (either internally or through the agency of outsourcing). 112 Measures which an education provider may take to demonstrate compliance with the student support services standards include ensuring that staff of institutions are aware of the specialised services available for the student with disability. 113 Staff must also be provided with information to assist the student to access the required services, necessary specialised equipment and appropriately trained support staff. 114 In view of the obvious and significant cost implications arising from the training and development of support services staff and the provision of the specialised services and equipment, it can be expected that providers will raise the defence of unjustifiable hardship, particularly if they are smaller providers with limited financial resources.

sec.title: Harassment and victimisation
sec.p: Students with disabilities do tend to experience isolation and bullying in the school environment, and, for their education to be delivered in as inclusive an environment as possible, the attitudes of other non-disabled students towards them is a weighty factor to be addressed. Part 8 of the Education Standards is therefore devoted to prescribing standards relating to the protection of students with disabilities from harassment and victimisation. 115 The overall effect of these standards is to require the education provider to implement strategies and programmes to support the right of students with disabilities to participate in education or training in a learning environment that is free from discrimination caused by harassment or victimisation on the basis of their disability. The term ‘harassment’ is defined to include an action taken in relation to a person’s disability ‘that is reasonably likely, in all the circumstances, to humiliate, offend, intimidate or distress the person’. 116 The education provider’s legal obligation in this regard is a requirement to develop and implement strategies and programmes to prevent disability-based harassment or victimisation of a student. This obligation includes taking reasonable steps to ensure that staff and students are informed about the obligation not to harass or victimise students with disabilities and about complaint mechanisms available to a student who suffers harassment or victimisation. 117 Measures which education providers may take in compliance with the standards on harassment and victimisation include an explicit prohibition of disability-based harassment and victimisation contained in the provider’s codes of conduct for its staff and students and the offer of awareness-raising professional development programmes to the provider’s staff to ensure that harassment and victimisation policies are known and understood by staff. 118

sec.title: Unjustifiable hardship
sec.p: If it appears that an education provider has discriminated against a student with a disability under the Disability Discrimination Act 1992 , it can seek to avoid a finding of unlawful discrimination thereunder by demonstrating that to comply with the Act and the Education Standards would constitute unjustifiable hardship for the institution under Section 11 119 of the Act and Part 10 of the Standards. As the respondent to the complaint, the education provider carries the burden of proving that implementing a reasonable adjustment would effectively impose an unjustifiable hardship on it. 120 The concepts of reasonable adjustment and unjustifiable hardship essentially balance the interests of students with disabilities with those of education providers and others. In adjudicating upon this defence, the court or tribunal will be required to undertake an individualised rather than general investigation. 121 According to Paragraph 10.2(2) of the Education Standards, they do not render it unlawful for an education provider to fail to comply with a requirement of the Standards ‘if, and to the extent that, compliance would impose unjustifiable hardship on the provider’. All the same, the provider must comply with the Standards ‘to the maximum extent not involving unjustifiable hardship’. 122 Unlike the concept of ’reasonable adjustment’, the determination of which is assisted by the prescription of various criteria in Paragraph 3.4 of the Education Standards, the Standards do not prescribe any criteria for the determination of when a reasonable adjustment would amount to unjustifiable hardship. This is left to the operation of Section 11(1) of the parent Disability Discrimination Act 1992 (and ultimately to judicial interpretation). Nevertheless, Paragraph 10.4 of the Education Standards provides that the Standards ‘do not render it unlawful for an education provider to isolate, or discriminate against, a student with a disability if the disability is an infectious disease or other condition and it is reasonably necessary to so isolate or discriminate to protect the health and welfare of the student with a disability or the health and welfare of others’. 123

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Over the past 40 years or so, the United Nations has pursued a trinity of aims in evolving international standards on behalf of persons with disabilities: promoting their independence, equalising opportunities available to them, and ensuring their full participation within the wider community. These standards – both legally binding and aspirational – are primarily sourced in the Convention on the Rights of the Child 1989 , the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities 2006 and the Standard Rules on the Equalization of Opportunities for Persons with Disabilities 1993 . Noble and aspirational principles remain largely symbolic in value, however, unless and until they can be meaningfully translated into the delivery of tangible benefits for the intended beneficiaries.

Such is the reality that the prosecution of these aims is highly resource-dependent in terms of both human and material resources. Indeed, the United Nations General Assembly has identified the ‘inadequate allocation of resources’ as ‘foremost’ among the major obstacles to the pursuit of these aims. 124 The problem is compounded when one considers that the vast majority of persons who suffer from some form of serious impairment live in developing countries 125 and that a disproportionate number of children in those countries are affected by various disabilities (Black, 1986: 369). In the context of children with disabilities, Article 23(4) of the Convention on the Rights of the Child 1989 accordingly states in part:

disp-quote.p: States Parties shall promote in the spirit of international co-operation the dissemination of and access to information concerning methods of rehabilitation education and vocational services, with the aim of enabling States Parties to improve their capabilities and skills and to widen their experience in these areas. In this regard, account shall be taken of the needs of developing countries.

sec.p: Article 32 of the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities 2006 is more prescriptive in articulating the obligation of States Parties to engage in international co-operation in meeting its obligations thereunder. Such co-operation extends beyond inter-State co-operation to also include partnership arrangements with international and regional organisations and civil society (particularly representative disability organisations). The modalities of such co-operation comprise, inter alia, exchange of information, training programmes and best practices, the provision of technical and economic assistance, and the sharing of accessible and assistive technologies. It is to be hoped that the States Parties to both Conventions, under the general co-ordination of UNESCO, UNICEF and the World Health Organization in consultation with leading non-governmental organisations working in the education and health care fields, and with appropriate guidance from the Committee on the Rights of the Child and the Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, will strive to fulfil this obligation conscientiously and in good faith.

Contemporary problems experienced by developed and developing States alike in the delivery of special education programmes for students with disabilities include an insufficient number of adequately trained special education teachers, lack of appropriate support staff, resource materials and facilities, inappropriate school placements and a failure to allocate the resources necessary to give disabled children opportunity within the educational system equal to that provided for non-disabled children. This may be counter-intuitive, bearing in mind the acknowledged untapped productive potential of persons with disabilities (M’Bow, 1979: 1, 12, 13) and Rule 6(8) of the Standard Rules on the Equalization of Opportunities for Persons with Disabilities 1993 which requires that ‘[a]t a minimum, students with disabilities should be afforded the same portion of educational resources as students without disabilities’. Even when enlightened legislatures have legislated to proscribe discrimination on the ground of impairment, they have left in place exemptions when admission of a disabled child to an educational institution would require provision of additional services or facilities which, in the circumstances, cannot reasonably be provided. Such exceptions to the operation of anti-discrimination legislation, if interpreted too generously and deferentially from the provider’s standpoint, provide scope for the denial of the disabled student’s right to education on the basis of such considerations as cost–benefit analyses and non-justiciable allocation of public resources (which generally have fallen beyond the scope of judicial review in many common law jurisdictions) (Hayes and MacAlpine, 1986: 36). The concept of undue burden/unjustifiable hardship should be interpreted purposively in light of the preambular aims and objectives of the international instruments so that this concept is narrowly construed and strictly applied in order to avoid undermining the educational rights of persons with disabilities. Although realpolitik constrains the full realisation of economic, social and cultural rights generally, the Limburg Principles indicate that a lack of public resources should not be readily invoked as an excuse or expedient to explain away slow progress in meeting the educational rights and needs of persons with disabilities.

Nevertheless, the interpretation and application of human rights do involve a balancing process between competing interests and considerations (Hodgson, 2003). It is self-evident that the costs involved in setting up some special education programmes will have the effect of withdrawing funds from other educational programmes, thereby constituting a detriment to the intended student beneficiaries of those programmes. The drafters of both the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities 2006 and the Australian Disability Discrimination Act 1992 have respectively acknowledged this through the explicit recognition of the distinct but related concepts of reasonable accommodation/reasonable adjustment and undue burden/unjustifiable hardship. One of the first challenges for the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities will be to strike the appropriate balance, in the course of its interpretational observations on the provisions of the Disabilities Convention and the interaction of these concepts, between the right of the disabled student to education and the extent of the obligations placed on educational providers and the State. While UN development of an international human rights normative framework has influenced legislative reform and policy development in many UN Member states over a long period, the experiences of some of these States in this particular area may well prove useful in turn in informing debate and influencing future thinking on how UN treaty-monitoring bodies elaborate upon the meaning of the substantive content of, and obligations inherent in, the standards and protections prescribed in the Disabilities Convention. The Committee can potentially be assisted in this task by the detailed promulgation of the rights, obligations and compliance measures propounded in the Australian Disability Standards for Education 2005. It is to be hoped that States Parties and the Committee will keep in mind the solemn obligation assumed by the former under Article 4(2) of the Disabilities Convention to take measures ‘to the maximum of [their] available resources’ and ‘within the framework of international cooperation’ with a view to progressively achieving the ‘full realization’ of the educational rights of persons with disabilities.
